Again, we get back to the madness, the degree of the madness.
So, I think the thing that I've had, maybe, is not that I had more money available than some of these people have the same means, but who are married, but I had the possibility of
putting money into something without worrying about what someone else's opinion might be of that, or without worrying about children being deprived.
So there have been times when I have spent more money than I should have.
I don't care.
Did you see this as an investment?
No.
Not until about 10 or 12 years ago, and then it was obvious that after Faulkner's death.
And I think the usual rule is when a writer dies, his books go down and die, not up and die.
But with Faulkner, that was not true, because it was like he had been underappreciated for so long that now things were firmly catching up.
I think any of the books from 1951 on, from Requiem for the Moon, I don't think any of those have appreciated terribly much.
But everything, up to and including collected stories, they just keep going up and up and up.
And of course anything that's right, anything with
I've got half a dozen with the signature, nothing inscribed, of course, to any individual.
They have not come cheaply.
However, you get Joe the Pro's catalog, I gather.
Sure.
You saw those signed limiteds that he has for $4,000 each, which is crazy, because I have three of them that he has listed them.
I showed my wife.
I said, look, I said, remember the books we paid $3,000 for?
We got a lot, you know?
in wonderful shape, you know, with the glassine.
And I said, this guy's good.
This guy's got a poor king of peace on him.
I think those prices are outrageously high.
I do, too.
But that's between us.
But that's what the market will bear.
That's a loop that you get into and you can't get into it.
What is something worth?
I mean, if you can find somebody that'll buy it, that's worth that.
At an auction.
What did the underbidder suggest paying at an auction?
Yeah, but I think that you'll have a hard time getting that kind of money back for that book.
$4,000 for the Wild Poms with Glacine is a lot of money, you know?
I think.
Yeah.
Well, Marky used to...
See, Monagy was so much a product of the 20s and 30s that she would say, having seen the Galsworthy books go up and down and then drop down, she would say, I hope I never see the day.
But those of you who collect Hemingway and the bottom may drop down, it is a day with Galsworthy.
That was her point of view.
So it never happened.
But she had been burned on the hot stove, and therefore she hadn't touched the stove again.
Well, Hemingway and Faulkner couldn't be harder.
They couldn't be more valuable.
Well, I have a very modest Hemingway collection.
Pretty nice Faulkner.

to go off and get manuscripts and letters and describe things.

with quotes and last cases and multiple copies and letters and manuscripts.

One of the reasons that finally, aside from the fact that I felt I'm getting to the point in my life where the money is perhaps more important than the collection, the major items in the collection were all in the bank.
They were all in the vault.
Really?
They were all out of sight.
Finally, the items that are really important, the totally unique items.
What are you going to do?
If any go down to the bank once a week and follow them?
Did you do that?
No.
Did you ever get out and look at them?
No.
So you owned them?
I owned them, and I knew they were there, and I cataloged them up to 1975, and I made some attempt to catalog them afterwards, but I had a lot of them.
Did you ever get bored with the collection?
No.
No, I never got bored with the collection.
It was not an easy decision to make to sell it, but once the decision was made, I did not have a problem with that.
If there's not a built-in dilemma, you know what I'm saying?
Once the decision was made, let's sell the collection and initiated the action to try to do it.
It did not turn out very quickly down to the institution.
So finally, it was turned over to Peter Howard of Serendipity, and he had made some arrangements with Jeff Marks.
And that was that.
And the price is something that we negotiated at 1 o'clock in the morning, walking on the north side of Chicago from a restaurant down into the loop.
There was an evening like tonight.
It was a marvelously bombing evening.
We walked and talked and negotiated with Peter.
Peter sold me some of the very nice side of the collection.
I've met Peter for a long time.
And so when an attempt to sell to an institution, which is what Bob and Christine are trying to do, when that didn't work out, then I talked to them and we all agreed with it.
Peter would be the next person that I would have a chance at it.
Now, did Peter sell it as a collection?
So he bought it from you at a price that was agreeable.
Yeah, and it's very likely that tomorrow you'll see some items from the collection.
And that's how I know I'm becoming mature, because I'm upset about that.
all these collection

Harvard.
That's the one I like to have.

The Houghton is the rare book, okay.

Not really.
What would I think about collecting?
For many years I thought of collecting photographs that I want.
I think it's too late for that.
Or why is that?
Hansel Adams, Diane Arbus, they're all too expensive.
And of course, photographs are like, books are very straightforward, but photographs are like paintings.
When you collect photographs, do you collect something that was printed from the studio of the photographer?
Or printed by the photographer.
Hansel Adams did all of his own prints.
Diane Arbus

Those books were in a game.
They weren't something.

And he had marvelous paintings.
The paintings.
Could you hang them where you live?
You think of that every day.
I'm not talking about now I'm talking about
while you're still building the great collection.
I think it's into the business of collecting.
When I cataloged the material in 1975, I said that in the introduction that collective involved among other things, I'm trying to be greed.
And I would maybe modify that now.
Greed means to have
to add to.
The joy of collecting is that most people have what their status is.
There's disorder in your life.
It may be in terms of your occupation, it may be in terms of your family, it may be in terms of your economic situation, and it's like collecting
You create your own little private world and you create order, you impose order on that.
And when I did that book in 1975, I was trying to impose order in my collection.
And someone would look at that and they would say, isn't that an interesting collection, the way he went out after certain holes and filled in those spaces.
But I don't think that's what happens at all.
You get what you can, and then you create the order afterwards.
And, for instance, I had, the first Faulkner letter I bought was written to Harrison Smith.
And publisher.
And it was publisher.
It was written in 19...
Biographical details very much
In February of 31, Sanctuary was published, and then in September of 31, East 13 was published.
And these two books made Faulkner's early career.
Before Sanctuary, Sardash and Ensemblature.
Marvelous books, you know.
not the sort of books that make clear.
It's like a movie actor who appears in certain films and become folk films and then suddenly appears in a film that basically is considered very important.
So Sanctuary has made that history.
So now, in the fall of 1931, suddenly people are very interested in that.
And he went to the Writers' Conference in Charlottesville in the fall.
He traveled to a number of places, but eventually he ended up in New York in November, December.
And Harrison Smith was having some financial difficulties.
Faulkner attended parties.
And then in December, he went home.
But the letter I had was written there thanking him for the Baltimore tickets.
I didn't know what the Baltimore tickets, I didn't know what that meant.
Eventually I found out that Harrison Smith had routed Faulkner so he could stop in Baltimore and visit H.L.
Lincoln.
And so that letter touched on that.
Then, in the same general period, Paul Romain from Casanova Books up in Milwaukee
is writing the poem about collecting his double dealer material in a book which eventually became Selma Gutti.
So Paul Romaine was a bookseller in Chicago for years and I eventually brought Paul Romaine's letters.
Did you go out and seek out Paul Romain?
He was a book dealer in Chicago, and Paul Romain told me before I heard elsewhere, oh yes, I used to deal with Paul Romain.
Did you go out on the hunt to find the primary sources we might say?
And this is what, again, this is what L.D.
did so well.
Really, L.D., he really did this very well.
I knew Paul Romain because he was a book dealer in Chicago.
And he would tell me about these partner letters, which he lost.
And eventually he found them.
And I bought them.
So what happened was,
And this is my example.
The 1930-1931 area, I suddenly found myself putting things together.
There was an issue when Faulkner was out east at the end of 1931.
One of the places he went to was Chapel Hill.
and he visited uh tony butita and and uh i don't remember his first name abernetti anyway contemple contemple was the was the literary publication in chapel hill
So, when Faulkner died, somebody sent me a clipping from the San Francisco Chronicle, a reminiscence by Tony Butita.
Well, Tony Butita was living in San Francisco in 1962 when Faulkner died.
So then I got a touch with Tony Butita.
Tony Butita.
Tony Butita.
B-U-T-T-I-T-T-A.
And Tony Utena had done a piece in the San Diego literature in 1937 or 1938 called William Faulkner, The Bright Man of Oxford.
So then I found out that involved with the issue of the temple, Butina had this letter from 1931.
So then, you see, I'm putting all this stuff together and I was able to buy these things.
So I got it.
Very knowledgeable about 1931 and Faulkner's life.
And if someday somebody wants to have a list of all the experts on Faulkner's life beside me, 1931.
So that's how you impose order after you have the opportunity to acquire it.
Did you think that you were building a scholarly archive or were you building a collection?

You kind of ride along

Satisfy yourself.

I know that.

Meanwhile, you see, in 1931, to put myself in the picture, I was two years old.
I'm writing a
I'm writing a master's and a THC.
I remember this in 1931, and I find out that Carl Peterson had this archive.
Could I come and see your stuff when you had it?
Yeah, okay, sure.
Did you ever get any requests like that?
Did you ever grant access of your materials for scholars?
The requests came from people that I already respected.
I mentioned Carvalho.
But he was interested in everything.

He was interviewing people.
Alas, he never wrote his biography, but he was interested in people before they died.
He taped material and transcribed material.
No one came out of nowhere.

I don't want you to think I'm doing anything.

Robert Neville.
Robert and Christine have a good place.

They tell me you're an okay person.
If I wanted to demolish an elderly to an okay person,

I will forward them to you with no comment.

I thought he was patronizing me.
And I guess I never got over feeling that.
But the very first time I visited him, his wife was pregnant with their second child.
And afterwards...
I stayed with him in Farmington.
And I wrote a note afterwards.
And she said that I was the very first person I would ever stand back who wrote afterwards and thanked her.
And she said it was a very difficult time because she was in an uncomfortable period.
I spent a number of times with them when there was lightning in the air.

Yes.

Oh, Mr.

Would you say that you were rivals in any way for the same material?
There is one point I really want to make, not to be published, but between me and you, that Faulkner is not the reason why he and I fell apart.
Well, there's the only reason why we temporarily came together.
He is the sort of person that he met at a reunion, at a dinner party.
business meeting, temperamentally, we haven't had any time.
And we never would have had any kind of friendship.
So Faulkner brought us together rather than separated.
Can I assume that he sought you out?

This is extraordinary.
Only once.
Only once.
And that was after we were no longer involved with each other.

Water up?

For 40 years, there have been very few unpleasant experiences.
I'd like to say that.
I've met a lot of people.
I never would have met otherwise.
Somebody has really, really delightful people.
When you would buy an exquisite association property, if you ever physically read that, are you buying an artifact?
You know, usually by the time you're buying something like that, the text is something you've already digested.
I think I was collecting for 10 or 15 years before I read what I would call the middle books.
And the middle books are Pylon and Absalom Absalom and Wild Poms.
Now, if I start collecting in 1948, which is in my book,
I'm buying Intruder in the Dust when it came out.
And I'm buying everything into that.
And I'm reading that.
And meanwhile I'm going back and I'm reading The Sound of the Fury and
and soldiers pay and so forth.
Those middle books, which I don't get around with for a long, long time.

I read Absalom Absalom in the first editions.
That's a tough ball.

I collect them.
It's the...
It's like you're getting about as close as you can get for most readers to the writer.

because the two people that most frequently I was paying off in installments, either Margie or Peter Howard.
Well, I'm not going to embarrass you by asking you what you paid for something and what you didn't pay.
But there certainly must have been things that you had to cringe at.
You said you gave yourself a price, but the collection was so important that you said, I have to have it.
Did that ever happen?
Well, at a certain point,
$500 is a tremendous amount of money, and then another point in my life, $3,000 is a tremendous amount of money.
As I got older and the notion of what constitutes a lot of money and change,
Things that I couldn't pay off in one month were something special.
We love black bread or anything.
Is there anything you ever passed on that you regret?
i don't think so i can't remember

Did you have a sense that you were building the preeminent collection while you were building it?
No.
The only thing I sensed for a long time was Linton Massey at the University of Virginia.
William Wisdom down in New Orleans, who in addition to his Thomas Malkin material, had some very fine Faulkner.
For a long time I sensed the notion that, gee, I'm about the youngest of the Faulkner collectors.
At about what point did you decide?
It was time to give the books a new life, meaning that you would have them.
And certainly the most valuable ones were in the vault, but they were yours.
So now it's time to move them along.
Something you thought about?
Really, a fairly long time ago.
I mean, between five and ten years before I actually sold it.
I realistically thought, someday, this material is going to be the basis of my retirement.
And so I'm going to have to decide when that time comes.
And I hope the collection can be kept together in a university or an institutional library.
That didn't happen.
It's like this is not a unique thing.
Your life is filled with decisions that become accretions of change rather than perhaps something.
Hey, today I decided I'm going to be an Army General.
It doesn't happen that way.
But, you know, Bradley Martin saw about his collection.
Is he still alive?
Oh, he's dead.
I went to most of the sales of his return, which realized $36 million or some such thing.
But he had lots of steel money, you know.
and that he had nothing to do throughout his life except by beautiful books.
And it would have been nice if the Ornithological Collection could have been kept together, but that was quite extremely extraordinary.
But the Bessemer Steel Trust, which was executor of the estate, decided that the estate was best served by selling it off.
So, you know, don't feel like you...
You've done a disservice to scholarship.
It happens all the time.
And I don't think that the popular study of

to pursue the cognitive scholarship is going to be as wonderful as your collection is everybody who bought those things are going to take care of them and i don't think that they necessarily have to be kept in my own feelings but i'm sure they're making cool it would have been nice if we could have gone to an institute but it didn't happen is that right it was not
